Award.AwardTitle: IUSE Collaborative Research: Data Computing for All: Developing an Introductory Data Science Course in Flipped Format

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, Data Computing for All: Developing an Introductory Data Science Course in Flipped Format, addresses two current issues: the need for more students to be familiar with the use of data in a variety of contexts and the need for instructional materials to support coursework in the "flipped classroom" format. The flipped classroom reverses the way time is spent by students. Instead of having information given to them in the classroom and then going away to practice using the new knowledge by themselves through homework problems, the students get the information before class time and then practice using it while the course instructor is present to help with misunderstandings and complexities. This allows the instructor to address the problems encountered by small groups of students, rather than lecturing to a large group without knowing who understands what.

Data science is essential for applications as diverse as genome sequencing and customer data analysis. Nearly every discipline has need of large scale data handling that requires computing and statistics in combination. More specifically, this course addresses an important need not only in computer and statistical sciences, but in all science, business, medical and engineering areas in general. The reliance on the effective use of vast amounts of data and the emergent field of data science is changing the operation of organizations across sectors. This project will not only provide new course in an important area in the STEM disciplines, but will also result in valuable educational research.

With the growing use of the flipped classroom model of learning, questions arise about its generalizability. Is it always the right approach? How difficult is it to prepare materials to teach a course in this way? This project will address these questions in the context of a new data science course for students with minimal background. The project is being developed in computer science and statistics departments at two different types of institutions. Both institutions have experience using the flipped approach and together have the expertise for data science. The course materials as well as the evaluation results will better enable other institutions to consider including introductory data science computing in their programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The importance and ubiquity of data in all aspects of business, government, society and learning are responsible for a major goal of this project: to design a course in Data Science that contributes to the education of a data-literate populace, especially those whose training is not primarily in technical areas. The investigators evaluated existing courses, collected real-world problems and developed the contents of such a course. A second major goal relates to the pedagogy employed. Educational research suggests that active learning, in which students take major responsibility for their own understanding, is a useful approach. One such technique arousing interest is the “flipped” (also known as “inverted”) classroom. In this case, students learn material through reading and exercises on their own, before they come to class, where the instructor guides them through clarification and discussion. This project’s relevant goal was to use, evaluate and share with the community its experience with active learning techniques. In keeping with the goal of educating a diverse population, the course would not impose prerequisites. Students majoring in subjects other than computing or statistics would be a major target of the course, as would minority students.

The investigators intended to demonstrate the intellectual merit of the project by disseminating their results in competitive venues respected by their peers. A related goal is to create an interdisciplinary community of Data Science instructors and users for sharing classroom experiences: syllabi, examples and teaching methods. The outcomes of the project, we are happy to report, succeeded in meeting these goals.

Indeed, over the course of the grant’s tenure, the five primary investigators on this grant, representing two institutions: Villanova University, a national research institution, and Winston Salem State University, an HBCU (Historically Black University), organized, offered and analyzed nine runs of Data Science courses between the two institutions. The offerings provided various emphases and tools: some used the Python computer language as the main tool for teaching data visualization, data wrangling and machine learning; others used R for teaching visualization, wrangling, text mining and statistical learning; others adopted a hybrid approach – programming with Python and visualization with JMP. All courses included units on ethics. These courses covered semesters from fall, 2015 through spring, 2018, when the grant terminated. Importantly, the effort continues to be sustained, with further courses taught or planned in fall, 2018 and spring, 2019.

Besides the varied approaches of computer science and statistics, the student population of these courses varied, with classes from freshmen to seniors all represented (one iteration was restricted to freshmen), and majors representing computing, mathematics, business, and other.

Each offering was assessed for both attitudinal and learning factors, and the results were shared with peer scholars and the Data Science community, as described below. The results were encouraging: learners did achieve the courses’ academic goals, and they did appreciate the importance of data in their fields of interest. On the pedagogy side, their learning was enhanced by their active learning. However, the flipped classroom approach was problematic for first-year students, who, generally, did not possess the maturity to take responsibility for independent learning.

The design and development of the offerings were based on evaluations of existing courses, surveys of appropriate resources and datasets, including, notably, motivating examples based on text mining of Tweets from Twitter. They also resulted in the creation of instructional materials.

The investigators shared their findings in both scholarly, competitive publications and conferences (dissemination demonstrating intellectual merit) and in community-building efforts (promoting the broader impact of the project). In addition, they have taken on leadership roles at the national level.  Here are summaries of both kinds of activities. Details may be found in the project website, mentioned below.

Scholarly peer-reviewed or invited publications and presentations were created and disseminated. They included respected venues such as SIGCSE (Special Interest Group in Computer Science Education), 2016, 2018; ITiCSE (Innovations and Technology in Computer Science Education), 2017, 2018; ADMI (Association of Computer/Information Sciences and Engineering Departments at Minority Institutions), 2016; AIMSA (Artificial Intelligence Methodology, Systems Applications), 2016; ICCS (International Conference on Computational Science), 2017; USCOTS (US Conference on Teaching Statistics), 2015; Electronic Conference on Teaching Statistics, 2018; and AMATYC (American Mathematical Association of Two-Year Colleges) Conference, 2018.

Outreach to the community took various forms, in addition to the dissemination mentioned above. Notable are the Project Website (http://oneup.wssu.edu/iis/datascience.html) and the Data Science Community one (http://www.computingportal.org/DataScienceCommunity). Also important are the Birds-of-Feather sessions at SIGCSE facilitated by the investigators in three consecutive years, where attendance skyrocketed from 40 colleagues in 2016 to over 100 in 2018. Workshops for the community with participation by project investigators also took place, in Arlington, VA (2015).  This work also informed DataFest Philly, hosted at Villanova in 2017 and 2018.  The enthusiastic and ongoing participation of instructors in these activities are promising signs of the project’s continuing impact.
